body:
I'm having trouble doing end-to-end builds because sourceforge is timing out today.

That encouraged me to get around to playing with `spack mirror` and it doesn't quite do what I assumed (dangerous word, that...) it did.

I was hoping that `spack mirror create -d /path/to/dir emacs@25.1`  would figure out all of the packages and versions that would be used to install that and go get them all.

I also thought that `spack mirror add` would add the dependencies for additional packages to an existing mirror.

Is there a way to abuse some combination of `spack fetch` and `spack mirror` to grab all of the things needed to install my apps given spec's for them?

Failling that, 

```
spack spec -y emacs@25.1+X | frobicator > list; spack mirror create -d ... -f list
```

might work, give a little `go` magic to write the frobnicator (or perhaps practicing my `python` magic would be good for me, except I worry about [this kind of thing...](https://youtu.be/J3cARml0TZ8?t=5m13s)[audio, but safe for work...]).
title: Is there a way to mirror a package and its dependencies?
